subject: Re: [junit] Warnings
msgSnippet: ... What you encountered is *not* a warning thrown by java code - in fact there is no concept of a warning at runtime as far as Java is concerned. What you
messageBody:
vaishnavi krishnan schrieb:
> Hi All,
> I am working on JUnit for automating my tests and want to know if the warnings thrown by the Java Code that I use can cause my tests to fail.
> For example, I encountered the following warning in trying to run my JUnit test:
>
> log4j:WARN No appenders could be found for logger (oracle.sysman.core.model.logmgmt.common.LogMgmtModelUtils).
> log4j:WARN Please initialize the log4j system properly.
>
> I want to know the extent to which JUnit deals with warnings in general. Are warnings a hinderance for my tests to succeed?
> Kindly let me know in this regard.

What you encountered is *not* "a warning thrown by java code" - in fact
there is no concept of a warning at runtime as far as Java is concerned.

What you encountered is a message to the console from log4j. That it
contains a "WARN" string has no effect on how your code runs at all.

Of course the message *could* indicate that there is a problem that will
cause your code to not function as expected, which could let tests fail.
But then the same would be true if log4j did not write the warning
message to the console. The message itself won't have any effect on
JUnit at all.

Does that help?

Cheers, Ilja
